results.name: default/mysql-service

error.Text: Service has not ready endpoints, pods: [Pod/mysql-deployment-9f4b6648b-z5gcb], expected 1

results.details:
Error: The service has no ready endpoints because the specified pod is not ready, though one is expected.

Solution: 
1. Check pod status with `kubectl get pods`.
2. Inspect pod logs using `kubectl logs Pod/mysql-deployment-9f4b6648b-z5gcb`.
3. Ensure readiness probes are correctly configured.
4. Verify pod dependencies and configurations.

results.name: default/wordpress-service

error.Text: Service has not ready endpoints, pods: [Pod/wordpress-deployment-6f965f955c-5vmq9], expected 1

results.details:
Error: The service is missing ready endpoints because the specified pod is not ready.

Solution: 
1. Check pod status with `kubectl get pods`.
2. Inspect pod details using `kubectl describe pod wordpress-deployment-6f965f955c-5vmq9`.
3. Resolve any issues (e.g., image pull errors, crash loops).
4. Ensure readiness probes are correctly configured.

results.name: default/mysql-deployment-9f4b6648b-z5gcb
results.details:
Error: Kubernetes is having trouble pulling the "mysql:latest" image from the container registry.

Solution: 
1. Check internet connectivity.
2. Verify the image name and tag.
3. Ensure Docker Hub is accessible.
4. Check Kubernetes node permissions.
5. Try a specific version tag instead of "latest".

results.name: default/wordpress-deployment-6f965f955c-5vmq9
results.details:
Error: Kubernetes is having trouble pulling the "wordpress:latest" image from the container registry.

Solution: 
1. Check internet connectivity.
2. Verify the image name and tag.
3. Ensure Docker Hub is accessible.
4. Check for rate limits on Docker Hub.
5. Try pulling the image manually with `docker pull wordpress:latest`.
